metadata.titleEn: A dataset of leaf traits on the Tibetan Plateau (2018-2021)
metadata.description: The dataset compiled 11 leaf traits in 468 species (mainly herbs and shrubs) at 336 sampling sites on the surface and the northern edge of the Tibetan Plateau, including leaf thickness, leaf dry weight, leaf fresh weight, leaf dry-matter content, leaf water content, leaf area, specific leaf area, leaf mass per area, leaf carbon, leaf nitrogen and leaf phosphorus content. The geographical coordinates, bioclimatic indicators, interference intensity and vegetation types of each sampling site were also recorded. These data were directly obtained by the research team from 2018 to 2021 through field plot investigation, leaf collection and trait measurement. These data could provide solid data support for effectively quantifying the modern ecological features of alpine ecosystems, further evaluating the response of alpine ecosystem to climate change and human disturbances and improving the next-generation vegetation model. It could be a great contribution to the regional and global plant trait databases.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in Excel format, which contains the information of three data sheets, namely: (a) a data sheet named ‘variables’ describing header information of the geographical coordinates, climate and traits in the dataset; (b) a data sheet (site information) reporting the site location and climate data; and (c) a data sheet (plant traits) of the complete trait data of each plant species in each sampling site.

background: Functional trait databases are emerging as a crucial tool for a wide range of ecological studies, including next-generation vegetation modelling across the world. However, few large-scale studies have been reported on plant traits in the Tibetan Plateau (TP), the cradle of East Asian flora and fauna with specific alpine ecosystems, and no report on plant trait databases could be found. Plant traits of morphological, anatomical, physiological and phenological characteristics respond to changes in the living environment, affect ecosystem functions and drive species coexistence under environmental constraints. Over the past 3 decades, a growing body of trait analyses has quantified the global and regional distribution patterns of key functional traits, such as leaf, seed size, plant height, wood, plant form and function, root and flower. Such studies have successfully linked plant traits with environmental changes, natural and anthropogenic disturbances and ecosystem functions. Findings from plant trait–environment–ecosystem function interaction could be further utilised to map the spatial pattern of plant traits, build the next generation of vegetation models, predict vegetation distribution and function and be incorporated into the Earth system model. New insights into ecosystem traits and the trait network are bridging multiple dimensions of biology, macroecology and geoscience. All these works require global and regional plant trait databases, such as the TRY, Growth-Form, Global Inventory of Floras and Traits, Fine-Root, GRoot and tundra traits and the Plant Trait for Mediterranean Basin Species (BROT), China traits, AusTraits and LT-Brazil. However, the Earth still has undersampled regions. The Tibetan Plateau (TP) includes the two major regions of Qinghai Province and the Xizang Autonomous Region and partial areas from north-western Gansu Province, southern Xinjiang Autonomous Region, western Sichuan Province and north-western Yunnan Province in China and is also called the “Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau”. As the world’s “Third Pole”, the “Asia Water Tower” and the cradle of East Asian flora, the TP is the most underrepresented region in global and regional plant trait databases. The first version of the Chinese plant trait database does not contain data from the TP, and the global plant trait database TRY has only a few collections from various sources with non-systematic sampling. Field-based, local studies of plant functional traits on the TP have made some interesting advances. For example, Luo et al. (2005) linked the plant traits with ecosystem functions, He et al. (2006) explored the influencing factors on plant traits, Geng et al. (2014) quantified the patterns of plant trait correlations between above- and below-ground components, Wang et al. (2020) compared their work with the global dataset, and Xu et al. (2021) analysed the mechanism of plant trait variation along the altitude pattern. However, such works, where the sampling sites have been mostly along the main roads in the eastern TP, were also limited. Plant trait records from the central to western TP are extremely rare. However, the TP has the richest temperate alpine flora and the most abundant plant diversity in the world. It was also an evolutionary cradle for the herbaceous genera of China. The uplift of the TP and its unique alpine vegetation are important to the monsoon climate system and vegetation of East Asia and regional and global climate change studies. As the largest and highest plateau in the world, the TP has not only changed the regional and global climate system, geological structure, topography and hydrology, but has also influenced the evolution of the flora, fauna and biodiversity strongly. It has 8876 vascular species from 1371 genera and 211 families, including 6475 herbaceous and 2401 woody plants, of which 1706 were endemic to the TP, and has three biodiversity hotspots of the world. Vegetation changes from south-east to north-west, from lowland broad-leaved evergreen forests, including tropical rainforest and subtropical evergreen forest, montane mixed evergreen and deciduous forest, subalpine conifer forest to alpine shrubland, meadow, steppe and desert along an annual precipitation gradient from ca. 3000 to 50 mm. In physiognomy, the unique alpine vegetation looks similar to the arctic tundra but has different species composition. The plateau has amplified changes in climates, and rapid climate change has led to profound changes in alpine species and ecosystems. Plant traits, as the link amongst species, environment and ecosystem functions, are the best tools to study the impacts of climate change on vegetation.
research objective: In this work, a TP leaf trait dataset (TiP-Leaf) was established, and 11 leaf traits from 468 species of 1692 leaf samples were collected from 336 sites across five of the six vegetation types on the TP. The dataset could provide solid data support to effectively quantify the modern ecological features of alpine ecosystems, thereby further evaluating the response of alpine ecosystems to climate change and human disturbances and improving the next-generation vegetation model. This dataset is not only an update of the Chinese plant trait database, but is also a great contribution to the global trait database. Therefore, the establishment of the TP plant trait database and further analysis of plant trait–environment–ecosystem function relationships are of great significance to understanding the future change and sustainable development of the unique alpine vegetation on the roof of the world.
challenges: However, the dataset also presents some unavoidable limitations. For example, the establishment of sampling sites and the judgment of dominant and common species are mostly subjective. The leaves of some plants are extremely small, resulting in incomplete recognition when scanning the LA. Due to harsh field conditions, measuring the plant traits in time occasionally becomes impossible. Preventing some leaves from losing too much water to withering is still inevitable, although we have taken protective measures for the leaves. Inadequate collection of some leaf samples results in fewer data of plant chemical element content than that of morphological traits. In any case, performing large-scale collection of plant traits on the TP, which requires a lot of manpower and material resources as well as overcoming the adverse environment of high altitude and extreme variability, is not easy.
methods: The leaf traits of the dominant and common plant species of the TP distributed mostly across the plateau surface were sampled and measured from July to August in the summer of 2018–2021. Vegetation surveys were conducted in four regions, namely the source area of the Three Rivers in Qinghai Province in the north-eastern TP (2018), the southern Xizang Autonomous Region in the south-eastern and central TP (2019), Ngari Prefecture in the north-western TP and the Qaidam Basin of the north-eastern TP (2020), and the Qilian Mountains, the Altun Mountains and the Kunlun Mountains in the northern margin of the TP, passing through the southern margin of the Tarim Basin in Xinjiang Autonomous Region (2021). Considering the zonal vegetation types and the precipitation gradient, 336 sites were selected to investigate the vegetation with less grazing and other anthropogenic disturbances. Shrubby and herbaceous vegetation was mainly selected (332 sites) along with the forest vegetation at the four sites (but removed for further analysis). At each site, one to three plots were set up to survey the species composition, abundance, coverage and plant height. The plot areas for herbaceous vegetation, shrubby vegetation and forest vegetation were 1 m ×1 m, 2 m×2 m or 5 m ×5 m and 10 m×10 m, respectively. Geographical locations, natural and human disturbances, and vegetation types were also recorded. The dominant and common plant species at each site were determined by visual inspection, the leaf samples of these plants were picked up, and the leaf traits were measured. At each site, two to three mature and disease-free complete leaves from each individual of dominant and common plant species were collected, and at least 30 individuals were selected to meet the needs of trait measurement and element analysis. When the single leaf was small, microphyllous or leptophyllous, 100–200 leaves were picked. In total, 11 leaf functional traits (e.g. leaf thickness, LT; fresh weight, FW; dry weight, DW; leaf dry-matter content, LDMC; leaf water content, LWC; leaf area, LA; specific leaf area, SLA; leaf mass per area, LMA; leaf carbon content, LCC; leaf nitrogen content, LNC; leaf phosphorus content, LPC) were measured and calculated on the basis of the handbook of standardised measurement for plant functional traits worldwide. LT (mm) was measured on the sampling day by using Vernier callipers with an accuracy of 0.01 mm. The thickness in the middle of the vein and margin of each leaf was measured, and then the average of the five leaves was taken as the LT of a species. In addition to LT, 20–30 leaves for normal-leaved plants and 100–200 leaves for small- to leptophyll-leaved plants were generally selected for other trait variable measurements. FW (g) was obtained by weighing with a 1 /100 electronic balance. Subsequently, the fresh leaves were oven dried at 75 ◦C for 48–72 h to obtain the DW (g). LDMC was measured as follows: LDMC (g g−1) =DW/FW. LA (cm 2) was measured using a scanner (EPSON Perfection V 700 Photo Scanner) and software (WinFOLIA Pro, Canada). SLA and LMA were measured as follows: SLA (cm2 g−1) =LA/DW and LMA (g m −2) =DW/LA ×104. The dried leaves were further used for chemical analysis. LCC (mg g−1), LNC (mg g−1) and LPC (mg g−1) were determined by the outside-temperature hot potassium dichromate oxidation–volumetric method, the distillation–titration method and the vanadium molybdate yellow colorimetric method, respectively.
dataset: In this work, an extensive dataset of 11 leaf functional traits (TiP-Leaf), mainly for herbs and shrubs and a few trees on the TP, was compiled through field surveys. The TiP-Leaf dataset, which was compiled from 336 sites distributed mainly on the plateau surface and the northern margin of the TP across alpine and temperate vegetation regions and sampled from 2018 to 2021, contained 1692 morphological trait measurements of leaf thickness, leaf fresh weight, leaf dry weight, leaf dry-matter content, leaf water content, leaf area, specific leaf area and leaf mass per area and 1645 chemical element trait measurements of leaf carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus contents. Thus, 468 species that belong to 184 genera and 51 families were obtained and measured. In addition to leaf trait measurements, the geographic coordinates, bioclimate variables, disturbance intensities and vegetation types of each site were also recorded. The dataset, which is available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (TPDC; Jin et al., 2022a; https://doi.org/10.11888/Terre.tpdc.272516), can make a great contribution to the regional and global plant trait databases.

Verification.Question: Were the plant species for data collection on the Tibetan Plateau selected based on visual inspection for identifying dominant and common species?

Disjunctive.Question: Does the data collection method focus more on field plot investigation, remote sensing, or laboratory analysis?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary methods used for collecting leaf trait data on the Tibetan Plateau, and how are they applied in field conditions?
What challenges are associated with data collection of plant traits on the Tibetan Plateau, and how do they affect the data quality?
Where can researchers access datasets related to leaf traits on the Tibetan Plateau, and what information do these datasets typically contain?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for measuring leaf traits in alpine ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A data collection method for measuring leaf traits in alpine ecosystems involves field plot investigation, leaf collection, and trait measurement. Specifically, the leaf traits of dominant and common plant species are sampled and measured in summer months from various sites across the Tibetan Plateau. Measurements include leaf thickness, dry and fresh weight, leaf area, and chemical composition, utilizing tools like Vernier callipers and electronic balances.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced during large-scale plant trait data collection in high-altitude regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced during large-scale plant trait data collection in high-altitude regions includes difficulties in establishing sampling sites and judging dominant species, as these are mostly subjective decisions. Additionally, harsh field conditions can impede timely measurements, and small leaf sizes can result in incomplete recognition during scanning processes.

Example.Question: Could you describe an example of how plant trait datasets from underrepresented regions can contribute to global ecological studies?
Example.Answer: An example of how plant trait datasets from underrepresented regions, such as the Tibetan Plateau, can contribute to global ecological studies is by providing data support to quantify modern ecological features, evaluate the response of ecosystems to climate change, and improve vegetation models. These datasets are crucial for understanding plant trait-environment-ecosystem function relationships in unique alpine vegetation.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of leaf traits in datasets collected from alpine ecosystems on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: leaf thickness, leaf dry weight, leaf fresh weight, leaf dry-matter content, leaf water content, leaf area, specific leaf area, leaf mass per area, leaf carbon content, leaf nitrogen content, leaf phosphorus content, geographical coordinates, bioclimatic indicators, interference intensity, vegetation types

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges faced in collecting plant trait data in high-altitude and extreme environments like the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: subjective establishment of sampling sites, difficulty in recognizing extremely small leaves, harsh field conditions, inevitable loss of leaf water content, inadequate collection of some leaf samples, fewer data on plant chemical element content compared to morphological traits

Feature Specification.Question: What are the methodologies employed for measuring leaf traits in remote and diverse vegetation types on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: leaf thickness, fresh weight, dry weight, leaf dry-matter content, leaf water content, leaf area, leaf carbon content, leaf nitrogen content, leaf phosphorus content

Quantification.Question: How many leaf functional traits were quantified in the data collection method for plant species on the Tibetan Plateau?
How many species were sampled and measured for leaf traits on the Tibetan Plateau from 2018 to 2021?
How many sites were selected for the vegetation survey on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'leaf functional traits' in the context of data collection for plant studies?
Definition.Answer: Leaf functional traits refer to measurable features of leaves, such as leaf thickness, leaf dry weight, leaf fresh weight, leaf dry-matter content, leaf water content, leaf area, specific leaf area, leaf mass per area, leaf carbon, leaf nitrogen, and leaf phosphorus content, which are collected to understand plant responses to their environments and their role in ecosystem functions.

Definition.Question: How is 'interference intensity' defined when collecting plant trait data on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Interference intensity in plant trait data collection refers to the measure of human or natural disturbances at the sampling sites, which is recorded alongside geographical coordinates, bioclimatic indicators, and vegetation types to assess their impact on plant traits.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method for leaf traits on the Tibetan Plateau compare to those used in other alpine or tundra regions in terms of logistical challenges and sampling strategies?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection method for leaf traits on the Tibetan Plateau involves field plot investigations with sampling from July to August over several years, focusing on dominant and common species across different vegetation types. This requires overcoming high-altitude challenges and ensuring minimal human disturbances. Similar methods in other alpine or tundra regions might face comparable logistical challenges but could differ in sampling strategies due to regional ecological differences and specific research focuses.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection challenges faced by researchers collecting plant trait data in the Tibetan Plateau compared to those in more temperate regions?
Comparison.Answer: Researchers collecting plant trait data in the Tibetan Plateau face challenges such as harsh field conditions, high altitude, and extreme variability in climate, which can affect timely measurements and preservation of leaf samples. In contrast, more temperate regions might have milder climate conditions and easier accessibility, reducing some of these challenges but potentially introducing others, such as different types of human disturbances or biodiversity considerations.

Interpretation.Question: How can the challenges of subjective site selection and species identification in data collection be addressed to improve the accuracy of ecological datasets in alpine environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges of subjective site selection and species identification in data collection can be addressed by implementing more standardized and objective measures for determining sampling sites and identifying species. Researchers could use more advanced tools such as remote sensing, geographic information systems (GIS), and machine learning algorithms to aid in objective site selection and species identification. Additionally, increasing training and calibration exercises for field teams can help reduce subjectivity and improve consistency in data collection methods.

Interpretation.Question: What considerations should be taken into account when measuring leaf traits in harsh environmental conditions to ensure data reliability?
Interpretation.Answer: When measuring leaf traits in harsh environmental conditions, considerations should include implementing protective measures to prevent leaves from losing too much water, ensuring timely collection and measurement of samples to avoid degradation, and using equipment suitable for harsh conditions, such as portable field instruments. It is also important to plan for contingencies, such as having backup equipment and additional human resources, to address unforeseen challenges and variability in field conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges associated with collecting plant trait data on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in collecting plant trait data on the Tibetan Plateau are due to subjective establishment of sampling sites, difficulty in recognizing small leaves, harsh field conditions that hinder timely measurement, issues with preserving leaf moisture, and the demanding environment requiring significant resources and efforts.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might certain regions, like the Tibetan Plateau, be underrepresented in global plant trait databases?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The underrepresentation of regions like the Tibetan Plateau in global plant trait databases can be attributed to the lack of systematic sampling, limited field-based studies, and the logistical and environmental challenges of conducting research in such remote and difficult-to-access areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to incomplete data collection of plant chemical elements compared to morphological traits in alpine ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Incomplete data collection of plant chemical elements compared to morphological traits in alpine ecosystems is caused by inadequate collection of leaf samples, which results in fewer data for chemical elements, alongside challenges in preserving samples and conducting timely measurements in harsh field conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using subjective methods to establish sampling sites and determine dominant species in a dataset of leaf traits?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using subjective methods to establish sampling sites and determine dominant species can lead to biases in the dataset, as these methods rely on personal judgment, which may not be consistent or accurate. This could affect the representativeness of the data and the reliability of conclusions drawn from the dataset regarding plant trait distribution and ecosystem functions on the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of the incomplete recognition of small leaves during scanning for leaf area measurement in a dataset of plant traits?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incomplete recognition of small leaves during scanning for leaf area measurement can result in inaccurate data regarding the leaf area trait. This inaccuracy could propagate through subsequent calculations for specific leaf area and leaf mass per area, ultimately affecting the dataset's utility in understanding plant function, species distribution, and their response to environmental changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of collecting leaf trait data from such a diverse range of species on the Tibetan Plateau, and how might this data be used to improve ecological models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of collecting leaf trait data from a diverse range of species on the Tibetan Plateau is to effectively quantify the modern ecological features of alpine ecosystems, evaluate the response of these ecosystems to climate change and human disturbances, and improve the next-generation vegetation models. This dataset also aims to contribute to both regional and global plant trait databases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a plant trait database specifically for the Tibetan Plateau, and how does it address the underrepresentation of this region in global databases?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Establishing a plant trait database specifically for the Tibetan Plateau is crucial because it is the most underrepresented region in global and regional plant trait databases. By compiling and analyzing data from this unique region, the database helps to fill gaps in the global understanding of plant traits, their interactions with the environment, and ecosystem functions, thus addressing the lack of systematic sampling and data collection from this significant ecological area.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific challenges faced during the collection and measurement of plant traits in harsh field conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include the subjective establishment of sampling sites and determining dominant species, incomplete leaf recognition when scanning due to small leaf sizes, and difficulties in measuring plant traits promptly in harsh field conditions. Additionally, despite protective measures, preventing leaves from losing too much water is challenging, and inadequate leaf sample collection leads to fewer data on chemical elements compared to morphological traits.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are geographic coordinates, bioclimatic variables, and disturbance intensities recorded during data collection in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: During data collection, geographic locations are recorded alongside natural and human disturbances and vegetation types. The vegetation surveys are conducted across selected sites with less grazing and anthropogenic disturbances, and various data points are documented to provide comprehensive information about each sampling site.

Enablement.Question: What conditions must be met to effectively collect leaf trait data in challenging alpine environments like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection was conducted from July to August when weather conditions are generally more favorable, and sites with less grazing and anthropogenic disturbances were selected. Protective measures were necessary to prevent leaves from losing too much water due to harsh field conditions.

Enablement.Question: How do technological tools and measurement standards enable the precise collection of leaf trait data on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Technological tools like Vernier callipers and electronic balances enabled precise measurement of leaf traits such as thickness and fresh weight. Additionally, the use of a scanner and specialized software facilitated accurate leaf area measurements, while chemical analysis methods like the vanadium molybdate yellow colorimetric method were employed for determining leaf chemical contents.

Enablement.Question: What resources are necessary to conduct large-scale plant trait data collection across diverse regions of the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Conducting large-scale data collection required substantial manpower and material resources to overcome high-altitude and variable environmental conditions. The dataset compilation involved field surveys across multiple regions, which necessitated coordination and logistics to cover extensive and remote areas of the plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why might the establishment of sampling sites and the identification of dominant and common species be predominantly subjective in data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: The establishment of sampling sites and the judgment of dominant and common species are mostly subjective due to the necessity of visual inspection and decision-making based on field conditions, which can vary greatly across different regions of the Tibetan Plateau, leading to subjective assessments.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise in ensuring consistent measurement of plant traits in harsh field conditions, and how might these affect expected data quality?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include harsh field conditions that make timely measurement of plant traits difficult, and preventing leaves from losing water and withering. These issues can affect data quality by potentially leading to incomplete or inaccurate trait measurements despite protective measures.

Expectation.Question: Why might the collection of certain leaf samples result in fewer data on plant chemical element content compared to morphological traits?
Expectation.Answer: The collection of certain leaf samples might result in fewer data on chemical element content due to inadequate sample collection, which may be influenced by factors such as the small size of leaves and difficulties in obtaining sufficient quantities for chemical analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges associated with conducting large-scale collection of plant traits in regions like the Tibetan Plateau, and how might these challenges impact the data quality?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges include subjective establishment of sampling sites, difficulty in measuring plant traits due to harsh field conditions, and logistical issues such as preventing leaves from losing water. These challenges may result in incomplete data, particularly in chemical element content, and can affect the overall quality and reliability of the data collected.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can effectively capture leaf traits in challenging environments like the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods on the Tibetan Plateau involved field plot investigation and sampling during summer months from 2018 to 2021, targeting dominant and common plant species. The research team set up plots, conducted vegetation surveys, and measured leaf traits like thickness, dry weight, and chemical content, despite harsh conditions such as high altitudes and extreme climate variability.

Assertion.Question: I'm uncertain about the challenges researchers face when collecting plant trait data in remote and diverse ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers collecting plant trait data in remote ecosystems like the Tibetan Plateau face challenges such as subjective determination of sampling sites, incomplete recognition of small leaves, harsh field conditions that delay trait measurement, and issues with preventing leaf dehydration during collection.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets can be expanded to include underrepresented regions like the Tibetan Plateau in global plant trait databases.
Assertion.Answer: Expanding datasets to include underrepresented regions like the Tibetan Plateau involves conducting large-scale field surveys across diverse vegetation types, recording geographical and bioclimatic variables, and integrating data into global plant trait databases. This requires significant resources and overcoming logistical challenges inherent to remote and high-altitude environments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced during data collection on the Tibetan Plateau and propose potential strategies to overcome these issues.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges faced include subjective establishment of sampling sites, incomplete leaf recognition due to small leaf sizes, harsh field conditions affecting timely measurement, and difficulty in preventing leaves from withering. Strategies to overcome these issues could involve developing more objective site selection criteria, using advanced imaging techniques for better leaf recognition, employing field-ready tools to expedite measurements, and implementing improved leaf preservation methods during transport.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for gathering leaf traits on the Tibetan Plateau and suggest enhancements to improve data accuracy and coverage.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods involved sampling dominant and common plant species, conducting vegetation surveys, and measuring leaf traits such as thickness, fresh and dry weight, and element content. Enhancements could include expanding the range of sampling sites to include more diverse vegetation types, integrating remote sensing for wider spatial coverage, and using automated tools for more consistent trait measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential sources or strategies for expanding plant trait datasets in underrepresented regions like the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential sources for expanding datasets include collaborating with regional research institutions, utilizing citizen science programs to gather data from remote areas, and employing satellite data to identify new sampling locations. Strategies could also involve systematic sampling across varied environmental gradients and integrating existing global databases to fill gaps in regional data.
